0	http://reuters.com/article/us-georgia-usa-kerry-idUSKCN0ZM0RG	John Kerry commits more U.S. military aid for ex-Soviet Georgia	"
By Lesley Wroughton and Margarita Antidze
| TBILISI

TBILISI Secretary of State John Kerry told ex-Soviet Georgia that the United States would help it bolster its army as he reassured a close U.S. ally days before a NATO summit expected to focus on the threat a resurgent Russia poses.Kerry
column2: on his first visit to Georgia as Secretary of State
column3: made the commitment ahead of a NATO summit in Warsaw on Friday at which members of the Western military alliance plan to announce action to deter possible Russian military aggression.Georgia and former Soviet states such as Moldova and Ukraine have become increasingly concerned by Russia's intentions after the Kremlin annexed Ukraine's Crimea in 2014 and launched air strikes in Syria last year.Moscow says such fears are unfounded and based on what it calls anti-Russian hysteria.  In a memorandum of understanding signed on Wednesday by Kerry and Georgian Prime Minister Georgy Kvirikashvili
column4: the United States promised to bolster Georgia's ability to defend itself against potential threats.

column1: That meant greater military and security cooperation
column2: enhanced information sharing
column3: and help building up defense capacity
column4: such as improving combat readiness and supporting defense procurement
column5: the document said.Until now
column6: U.S. security support has focused on training Georgian troops for operations in Afghanistan and Iraq.""The United States stands firm in its commitment to Georgia's sovereignty
column7: independence
column8: and territorial integrity within its internationally recognized borders

column1: Georgia
column2: which is crisscrossed by strategically important oil and gas pipelines
column3: fought and lost a short war with Russia in 2008. Moscow then recognized two breakaway pro-Kremlin Georgian regions - South Ossetia and Abkhazia - as independent countries
column4: though most other countries have not.""Russia's occupation and militarization of parts of Georgia's territory are unacceptable
column5: said Kerry. ""We continue to call on Russia to fulfill its obligations under the 2008 ceasefire agreement
column6: including a withdrawal of its forces to pre-conflict positions.""

column1: Moscow for its part has accused the West
column2: notably Washington
column3: of stirring anti-Russian feelings in former Soviet states it deems part of its own sphere of influence.Kerry visits Ukraine next
column4: on Thursday
column5: before heading to Warsaw to join U.S. President Barack Obama for the NATO summit.In Ukraine
column6: Kerry's third visit there since Russia annexed Crimea
column7: he will focus on the implementation of the Minsk peace accords and the country's reform agenda. It will be Kerry's first chance to meet new Prime Minister Volodymyr Groysman. (Writing by Lesley Wroughton and Andrew Osborn; Editing by Larry King)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-guns-idUSKCN0ZM265	U.S. House Republicans battle each other on gun control	"
By Susan Cornwell and David Morgan
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON A divided Republican Party on Wednesday fought over gun control legislation that was cobbled together following last month's mass shooting in Orlando
column2: raising questions over U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan's ability to get the measure passed.While Democrats have said the gun control proposal put forward by Republican leaders was too weak
column3: an influential group of approximately 40 conservative House Republicans announced their opposition as well
column4: saying the plan did not do enough to protect gun buyers.The legislation fails ""to do enough to address the threat of radical Islamic terrorism
column5: according to a statement by the conservative Freedom Caucus. The group also complained of ""the inclusion of gun control provisions that fail to adequately protect due process.""With the Republican leadership's legislation under attack from both liberals and conservatives
column6: it was unclear whether Ryan could muster the 218 votes he would need for passage in the House of Representatives.Last month
column7: the Senate failed to approve any of several competing Republican and Democratic gun control proposals offered in the wake of the June 12 shooting at a gay night club in Orlando that killed 49 and injured 53 others.

column1: During the Senate debate
column2: Democratic lawmakers staged a sit-in on the House floor to pressure Republican leaders to pass legislation expanding background checks on gun sales and blocking gun purchases by people on terrorism watch lists.The Republican leadership bill
column3: announced last Friday
column4: would give the government three days to convince a judge that a gun sale should be blocked. Ryan said Wednesday that he intended to bring it to the floor for a vote this week or next
column5: but also noted changes were being sought by numerous lawmakers.""The last thing we're going to do is rush something to the floor that we don't have right
column6: Ryan said.

column1: Representative Matt Salmon of Arizona
column2: a Freedom Caucus member
column3: said he objected to Ryan pushing the bill without allowing it to be processed by relevant committees first.Salmon said that Ryan told House Republicans in a closed meeting that he was rushing the legislation to the House floor because ""there are members that need to have this vote"" for political reasons in swing districts that could go either Republican or Democratic in the Nov. 8 elections.Democrats
column4: meanwhile
column5: continued to pressure Ryan for votes on their more sweeping gun control measures.

column1: Representative John Larson of Connecticut
column2: a ringleader of the Democrats' sit-in
column3: said his fellow Democrats plan to support Republican mental health legislation that could help avert some mass shootings. Larson added he hoped it would be seen as an olive branch to Republicans toward progress on gun control.Scores of gun control advocates demonstrated outside the House chamber in sweltering heat on Wednesday morning
column4: as 91 people wearing orange t-shirts stood on the steps leading to the House demanding action.They represented the 91 people who
column5: according to government statistics
column6: die each day in the United States from gun violence. Many of them die as a result of suicide. (Reporting by David Morgan
column7: Susan Cornwell and Richard Cowan; Editing by James Dalgleish)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-college-idUSKCN0ZM1WW	Clinton offers plan to freeze some college debt
column2: cut tuition	"

column1: Democratic presidential contender Hillary Clinton on Wednesday proposed a temporary freeze on some student debt and the cutting of college tuition entirely for some families
column2: focusing on an issue important to supporters of her rival Bernie Sanders.Clinton's latest proposal includes a three-month moratorium for federal student loan payments and a new measure to eliminate in-state college tuition for families whose income does not exceed $125
column4: according to a release from her campaign. The proposal builds on her earlier plan for easing student debt loads for higher education.Clinton
column5: the former secretary of state and presumptive Democratic Party nominee
column6: is looking to win over supporters of Sanders
column7: the Vermont senator who was her main opponent for the nomination as he consistently sought to push the party left.The presumptive Republican nominee
column10: trying to use his outsider appeal to bring them over to his campaign.

column1: On Wednesday
column2: Clinton proposed using executive action to offer a three-month moratorium on student loan payments to all federal loan borrowers to offer help for borrowers to consolidate loans and find other methods to reduce their payments.

column1: She previously has released proposals to increase access to tuition grants
column2: push for income-based repayments
column3: and - like Sanders - to allow graduates to refinance student loans at lower interest rates.Sanders praised the new Clinton measures on Wednesday
column4: saying in a statement that he wanted ""to take this opportunity to applaud Secretary Clinton.""

column1: (Reporting by Luciana Lopez; Editing by Bill Trott)"
3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-afghanistan-republicans-idUSKCN0ZM1P5	Senior Republicans signal issues in Congress for Obama Afghan plan	"
WASHINGTON Representative Mac Thornberry
column2: the Republican chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives Armed Services Committee
column3: said on Wednesday that the White House must submit a supplemental funding request immediately to support President Barack Obama's plans to keep 8
column4: 400 troops in Afghanistan.Senator John McCain
column5: who leads the Senate Armed Services Committee
column6: said he welcomed Obama's decision but added in a statement: ""That said
column7: when the President himself describes the security situation in Afghanistan as 'precarious
column8: ' it is difficult to discern any strategic rationale for withdrawing 1
column9: 400 U.S. troops by the end of the year.""

column1: (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama)"
4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-afghanistan-idUSKCN0ZM1HT	Obama
column2: in shift
column3: says he will keep 8
column4: 400 U.S. troops in Afghanistan until 2017	"

column1: By Jeff Mason and Jonathan Landay
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON President Barack Obama
column2: calling Afghanistan's security situation precarious
column3: said on Wednesday he will keep U.S. troop levels there at 8
column4: 400 through the end of his administration rather than reducing them to 5
column5: 500 by year's end as previously planned.Obama
column6: in a statement at the White House
column7: said the role of U.S. forces in Afghanistan will remain unchanged: training and advising Afghan police and troops
column8: and supporting counterterrorism missions against the Taliban and other groups. Obama's presidency ends in January.Obama's plan still calls for a reduction in U.S. troop levels from the current roughly 9
column10: but not as much as previously planned.Obama
column11: who took office in 2009 pledging to wind down the U.S. wars in Iraq and Afghanistan
column12: said he had ended America's combat mission in Afghanistan. But he acknowledged that security concerns persist.""The security situation in Afghanistan remains precarious
column13: Obama said. ""The Taliban remains a threat. They've gained ground in some places.""Taliban forces now hold more territory in Afghanistan than at any time since the 2001 U.S.-led invasion
column14: according to recent United Nations estimates. The Islamic State group has also established a small presence in Afghanistan.

column1: Obama's decision
column2: which came after a review submitted last month by the U.S. commander in Afghanistan
column3: Army General John Nicholson
column4: drew some criticism inside and outside his administration.Some Pentagon officials said that it does nothing to address the deteriorating security situation in Afghanistan.""It's disappointing that the administration thinks that troop numbers are a substitute for a more comprehensive strategy
column5: said a U.S. defense official
column6: who spoke on condition of anonymity. ""This is neither the reduction that the White House seems to have wanted nor the current numbers that don't seem to be sufficient to deal with the security problem.""

column1: Mac Thornberry
column2: the Republican chairman of the House of Representatives Armed Services Committee
column3: criticized what he said was a new cap on U.S. troop levels.""It is time that the president level with the American people about what it will really take to achieve our goals in Afghanistan
column4: and how much it will cost
column5: Thornberry said in a statement. Obama spoke in advance of a NATO summit on Friday and Saturday in Warsaw
column6: Poland
column7: where alliance members are expected to confirm their support for the Kabul government.

column1: In addition to the U.S. forces
column2: there are about 3
column3: 000 other international troops in Afghanistan.U.S. troops have been in Afghanistan since the 2001 invasion launched by Obama's predecessor
column4: George W. Bush
column5: that toppled the Taliban leaders who harbored the al Qaeda organization responsible for the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States that killed about 3
column6: 000 people. It is America's longest war.During his announcement at the White House
column7: Obama was flanked by Defense Secretary Ash Carter and the top U.S. military officer
column9: chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. (Writing by David Alexander and Warren Strobel; Editing by Tim Ahmann and Will Dunham)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-panel-idUSKCN0ZM1KT	U.S. attorney general to testify before House panel on July 12	"
U.S. Attorney General Loretta Lynch will testify before the House Judiciary Committee on July 12 on a number of issues facing the Justice Department
column2: including the FBI's probe into Hillary Clinton's use of a personal email server
column3: the panel said on Wednesday.Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte said in a statement that the FBI's decision to not recommend charges against Clinton
column4: the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee
column5: raised questions. The panel is also expected to question Lynch on the attacks in Orlando
column6: Florida
column7: and San Bernardino

column1: (Reporting by Adam DeRose; Editing by Tim Ahmann)"
6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-comey-idUSKCN0ZM1IH	FBI Director Comey to testify before House panel on Thursday	"

FBI Director James Comey is set to testify before the U.S. House Oversight Committee on Thursday about the agency's decision not to recommend charges against Hillary Clinton over her use of a personal email server while serving at the State Department
column2: the panel said in a statement.In the statement on Wednesday
column3: Oversight Committee Chairman Jason Chaffetz said that Congress and the American people have a right to understand the FBI's investigation in the matter. The panel said the hearing is scheduled for 10 a.m.

column1: (Reporting by Adam DeRose)"
7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-analysis-idUSKCN0ZM1DA	Rebuke of Clinton over email use creates opening for Trump	"
By Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The FBI report scolding Democrat Hillary Clinton over her email practices as secretary of state plays into a chief vulnerability that her rival
column2: Republican Donald Trump
column3: hopes to exploit - wariness among U.S. voters about her trustworthiness.Clinton campaign spokesman Brian Fallon said the Federal Bureau of Investigation's recommendation against criminal charges for Clinton means the email matter ""is now resolved.""Yet even as he removed the threat of charges against the Democratic candidate
column4: FBI Director James Comey described Clinton's handling of classified information as ""extremely careless.""Trump
column5: the presumptive Republican nominee
column6: seized on that comment.""We're talking about serious stuff
column7: he told a rally in Raleigh
column8: North Carolina. ""The laws are very explicit.""The New York businessman has been struggling to unify the party around his candidacy
column9: and Republicans say Trump could use the issue to heal some of the rifts within his party while motivating conservatives to go to the polls in the Nov. 8 election.Indeed
column10: a main element of Trump's strategy for winning over Republicans who are lukewarm on his candidacy is to emphasize the importance of keeping Clinton out of the White House.""Clinton won the 'Comey primary' but Trump has the opportunity to drive home the lack of trust theme

column1: A Reuters/Ipsos poll from May 1-11 found that a majority of American adults do not think Clinton is an honest person. This included 89 percent of Republicans
column2: 72 percent of independents and 36 percent of Democrats.More than a quarter
column3: 27 percent
column4: of Clinton's own supporters did not think she is an honest person
column5: according to the poll.Democratic strategist Steve Elmendorf said Clinton needs to move quickly to get past the email episode and talk about issues central to her campaign. He predicted the issue will be short-lived as voters focus on the candidates' vice presidential running mates
column6: the nominating conventions and fall debates.""She made a mistake here
column7: there's no question about it
column9: a Democratic strategist who was chief strategist for 2004 nominee John Kerry

column1: But there's also justice in what she says
column2: that for 24 years the Republicans have relentlessly gone after Bill and Hillary Clinton. That has its impact and that impact you can see in her trust numbers. But this decision
column3: despite how anybody spins
column4: it not only helps her but in my view was indispensable to her
column5: Shrum said.Hours after Comey's announcement
column6: Trump's campaign sent an email soliciting money based on the Clinton email controversy. The big question for Republicans is whether their presumptive presidential nominee will be able to prosecute the case effectively against Clinton since he is still at war with fellow Republicans and has little in the way of campaign funds to pay for TV ads against her.""I don't think there's a way that Clinton can use this to raise anger at Republicans
column7: said Andy Smith
column8: director of the University of New Hampshire Survey Center. ""But the Republicans can certainly use this to raise anger at Clinton and the Democrats. Anger is a great motivator to get people out to vote.""

column1: Trump's initial response showed why Republicans continue to have concerns about him. Interviewed by Fox News' Bill O'Reilly
column2: Trump spent as much time criticizing Comey as he did Clinton. Comey is respected by Republicans and Democrats alike.""I have such respect for the FBI that I just don't understand what happened here
column3: Trump said. ""Everybody knows she's extremely guilty. And they really said she was guilty today and then they said we're not going to prosecute.""Ryan Williams
column4: a Republican strategist and former spokesman for 2012 nominee Mitt Romney
column5: called the FBI report a ""disqualifying event"" for Clinton.""Trump's singular focus should be that she acted inappropriately. But Trump has a knack for distracting from Hillary Clinton's scandals with his gaffes and missteps
column6: he said.Trump has been fighting allegations of anti-Semitism in recent days over his campaign's use of a Jewish star in a tweet attacking Clinton as corrupt. (Writing by Steve Holland; Editing by Caren Bohan and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-emails-idUSKCN0ZL1US	Clinton 'extremely careless' with emails
column2: but FBI recommends no charges	"

column1: By John Whitesides and Julia Edwards
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The FBI recommended on Tuesday that no criminal charges be filed over Hillary Clinton's use of private email servers while she was secretary of state
column2: but rebuked the Democratic U.S. presidential candidate for ""extremely careless"" handling of classified information.While FBI Director James Comey's announcement lifted a cloud of uncertainty that had loomed over Clinton's White House campaign
column3: his strong criticism of her judgment ignited a new attack on her over the email issue by Donald Trump
column4: her likely Republican opponent in the Nov. 8 election.Comey's comments are likely to reinforce what polls show are widespread public concerns about Clinton's honesty and trustworthiness. Republicans have pointed to the controversy as evidence that she considered herself above the law.House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan
column5: the highest- ranking elected U.S. Republican
column6: said in a statement that Comey's announcement ""defies explanation.""Ryan called on the FBI to release all of its findings in the case and said Comey would be called to testify before the House Oversight Committee. ""We need to know more
column7: Ryan told Fox News. In a lengthy statement on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's conclusions from its yearlong investigation
column8: Comey directly contradicted statements Clinton has made while defending her use of the private email setup.He said
column10: that the FBI found at least 110 emails that contained classified information when they were sent
column11: although Clinton has repeatedly said she never sent or received classified information on her private servers.""Although we did not find clear evidence that Secretary Clinton or her colleagues intended to violate laws governing the handling of the classified information
column12: there is evidence that they were extremely careless in their handling of very sensitive
column14: Comey said.But he said the FBI concluded ""no reasonable prosecutor"" would bring charges. ""Although the Department of Justice makes final decisions on matters like this
column15: we are expressing to Justice our view that no charges are appropriate in this case
column16: Comey told reporters in Washington.His recommendation will likely stand. The country's top prosecutor
column18: said on Friday she would accept the recommendations of career prosecutors and the FBI director on whether to charge Clinton for mishandling emails.'SHE LIED!'

column1: Clinton's campaign was anxious to move on after Comey's announcement
column2: saying in a statement it was pleased with the FBI decision.

column1: As the secretary has long said
column2: it was a mistake to use her personal email
column3: and she would not do it again. We are glad that this matter is now resolved
column4: spokesman Brian Fallon said.He did not respond to questions about Comey's rebuttal of the main arguments Clinton has offered in defense of her use of private email.At a rally in Raleigh
column5: North Carolina
column6: on Tuesday night
column7: Trump
column9: said the controversy should disqualify Clinton from being president and that her email system may well have been hacked by U.S. enemies.""Our enemies may have a blackmail file on crooked Hillary and this alone means that she should not be allowed to serve as president of the United States
column10: Trump said. ""We now know that she lied to the country when she said that she did not send classified information on her server. She lied!""Following Comey's late-morning remarks
column11: Clinton became one of the top trending topics on Twitter
column13: 000 tweets posted by 4 p.m. (2000 GMT). The overall sentiment was more negative than positive
column14: with about two negative tweets for every positive one
column15: according to social media analytics firm Zoomph.The FBI director's announcement came hours before Clinton's first campaign appearance with President Barack Obama
column18: where neither Obama nor Clinton mentioned the email probe. It also came less than three weeks before the Democratic National Convention at which Clinton is to be nominated as the party's candidate for the November election.

column1: NO 'INTENTIONAL MISCONDUCT'
The FBI has been investigating whether Clinton broke the law as result of personal email servers kept in her Chappaqua
column2: New York
column3: home while she was secretary of state from 2009 to 2013. One question is whether she mishandled classified information on the servers.As the investigation wound up
column4: Clinton underwent a voluntary 3-1/2-hour interview with the FBI on Saturday in Washington.Comey said the FBI did not find that Clinton or her colleagues intended to violate the law
column5: and that there was no ""intentional misconduct"" by her lawyers who sorted her emails.He said her staff should have known Clinton's private email was an improper place for classified information
column6: but added there was no evidence anyone had hacked Clinton's communications.Comey said
column7: however
column8: that ""hostile actors"" gained access to email accounts of people with whom Clinton corresponded  regularly. He also said she used email extensively while traveling ""in territory of sophisticated adversaries.""

column1: Experts routinely advise U.S. government officials not to bring important digital information to countries with a track record of aggressive cyber activity. Clinton traveled to more than 100 countries during her four years as top U.S. diplomat
column2: including trips to China and Russia
column3: considered among the most sophisticated U.S. cyber adversaries.The FBI found 110 emails in 52 email chains that contained information that was classified at the time the messages were sent
column4: Comey said. Eight of those chains contained ""top-secret"" information
column5: the highest level of government classification for material that could harm national security.A further 36 email chains contained ""secret"" information
column6: and eight ""confidential"" information
column7: he said. Agents also found three classified emails among the thousands Clinton never returned to the State Department.Comey said there were no previous cases that supported filing criminal charges against Clinton. Other cases had involved intentional mishandling of information
column9: the FBI recommended that former CIA Director David Petraeus be charged with a felony for his mishandling of classified information with his biographer
column10: with whom he was having an affair. In that case
column12: the FBI had evidence that Petraeus knew the information was highly classified. Petraeus eventually pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of mishandling classified information.Republican lawmakers have called for an independent investigation of Clinton
column13: saying they do not trust the Justice Department to handle the inquiry with impartiality.Republican criticism of the process heated up after Clinton's husband
column15: met privately with Lynch in Phoenix last week. Lynch
column17: said later she regretted the meeting and that she and the former president did not discuss the investigation. (Additional reporting by Jonathan Allen and Angela Moon in New York and Dustin Volz
column18: Steve Holland and Eric Beech in Washington; Editing by Jonathan Oatis and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-legal-idUSKCN0ZM04C	Lawyers: Legal precedent clears Clinton in email investigation	"
By Julia Edwards
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON In declining to seek prosecution of Hillary Clinton
column2: FBI Director James Comey said the former Secretary of State's handling of classified emails was ""extremely careless"" - conduct
column3: legal experts said
column4: that falls short of ""gross negligence
column5: a standard for criminal charges under the Espionage Act.""Although there is evidence of potential violations of the statutes regarding the handling of classified information
column6: our judgment is that no reasonable prosecutor would bring such a case
column7: Comey said in a news conference Tuesday detailing the FBI investigation and his decision.Several legal experts agreed with Comey's conclusion that there was no recent precedent for bringing such a case without evidence of willful intent or gross negligence
column8: and they said it would have been difficult to convince a jury to convict Clinton based on the evidence.""Extreme carelessness doesn't necessarily translate into gross negligence
column10: a professor of law at Loyola Law School in Los Angeles and former federal prosecutor. ""The only times I have seen these statutes used has been situations in which people knew they were disclosing classified
column12: or they could show they didn't really care
column13: Levenson said. Comey said investigators determined that Clinton exchanged 110 emails that contained government secrets and that she and her staff should have known the information was classified.But unlike other cases prosecuted under the Espionage Act
column14: the FBI has not suggested that Clinton intentionally shared government secrets with people not authorized to see them.The statute for charging gross negligence under the Espionage Act
column16: requires the information be ""removed from its proper place
column17: a tough legal requirement in the digital age
column19: a law professor at University of Texas.Vladeck said the law is not ""well suited for careless discussion of information in unsecured media that doesn't dispossess the government of that information or direct it right into the hands of a foreign power.""

column1: Previous cases charged under the Espionage Act have shown intent
column2: experts said.Defense attorney Abbe Lowell said Comey's decision was ""completely consistent"" with every case brought for leaking classified government information. Defendants in other cases include Stephen Kim
column3: Lowell's client who pleaded guilty to leaking State Department documents to the press
column4: as well as former C.I.A. Director General David Petraeus. He admitted to keeping classified information
column5: which he would also share with his biographer
column6: in his home
column7: while telling the government he had returned all such information.""The one common denominator of all such cases is that the individual involved intentionally sent material to those not authorized to receive it
column10: Lowell said.Comey said the FBI ""did not find clear evidence that Secretary Clinton or her colleagues intended to violate laws governing the handling of classified information."" But he said it did find ""evidence that they were extremely careless in their handling a very sensitive

column1: His recommendation
column2: which Attorney General Loretta Lynch previously said she would accept
column3: angered Republicans who said her actions should be punished. Republican presidential front runner Donald Trump reacted to the news from his Twitter account
column4: saying
column5: ""The system is rigged. General Petraeus got in trouble for far less.""In that case
column6: the FBI recommended a felony charge. But Attorney General Eric Holder pursued a misdemeanor under another part of the law
column7: and Petraeus pleaded guilty. He was sentenced to two years probation in 2015. The FBI had recordings of Petraeus acknowledging the information in notebooks in his home was highly classified. Petraeus also admitted to lying to the FBI about sharing the information with Paula Broadwell

column1: Steven Aftergood
column2: director of the Federation of American Scientists' Project on Government Secrecy
column3: said Clinton's cooperation with FBI investigators also may have helped her avoid charges.""There was no obstruction of justice
column4: no failure to cooperate truthfully with investigators
column5: no concealment of her activity
column6: Aftergood said.Legal precedent suggests that Clinton is unlikely to face a misdemeanor charge for recklessness because recent cases that ended with misdemeanors began as much larger felony charges against individuals who intended to leak information.In 2010
column7: Thomas Drake
column8: a whistleblower from the NationalSecurity Agency who helped expose the government's warrantless surveillance of Americans
column9: was charged with espionage after the government accused him of bringing five classified documents home. He denied the accusation
column10: and those charges were dropped. Drake pleaded guilty to one misdemeanor count for exceeding authorized use of a computer.""Somebody needs to ask Comey about my case
column12: who now works at an Apple store in Maryland
column13: wrote in an email late Tuesday.Former president Bill Clinton's national security adviser pleaded guilty in 2005 to smuggling classified documents out of the National Archives by stuffing them under his clothes. He was fined $50
column14: 000 and sentenced to two years of probation.  (Reporting by Julia Edwards in Washington; Additional reporting by Jonathan Allen and Noeleen Walder in New York; Editing by Amy Stevens and Lisa Girion)"
